===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|みょう|が}}
{{IPAchar|/mega/}} → {{IPAchar|/meuga/}} → {{IPAchar|/mjoːga/}}

From earlier ''mega'' (see below).<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref> The kanji spelling is an example of [[phonetic]] [[ateji]].<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref>

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|め|が}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=めが}}. Some sources<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref> mention that this might be a compound of {{m|ja|芽|tr=me||sprout}} + {{m|ja|香|tr=ka||fragrant}}. However, the semantics are backwards compared to most other Japanese compounds. In addition, this term appears in writings of the {{w|Nara period}} with the spellings {{m|ja|女}}{{m|ja|我}} and {{m|ja|売}}{{m|ja|我}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> The ''me'' syllable here is spelled phonetically with the so-called Type-A or {{m|ja|甲類|tr=kōrui}} reading of ''e<sub>1</sub>'', but {{m|ja|芽}} in {{etyl|ojp|-}} had the Type-B or {{m|ja|乙類|tr=otsurui}} reading of ''e<sub>2</sub>''. These two different ''e'' phonetic values were distinct in {{etyl|ojp|-}}, indicating that {{m|ja|芽|tr=me||sprout}} + {{m|ja|香|tr=ka||fragrant}} is not the actual derivation.

(For more details on {{etyl|ojp|-}} spellings and phonetic values, see {{pedia|Jōdai Tokushu Kanazukai}})

This reading is [[obsolete]] in modern Japanese.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=irr|めが}}

====Noun====
